Articles.Content:
Looked back at my flight records and:

[ATTACH=CONFIG]32128[/ATTACH]

|

How could that kerbal have possibly survived?
Are you saying pancakes can't fly spacecraft?
Would you rather the atmospheric deceleration on that steep re-entry have killed your Kerbals?

Would you rather the atmospheric deceleration on that steep re-entry have killed your Kerbals?

That'd make more sense. 15g = knock out the pilots, 40g = dead crew.

Would you rather the atmospheric deceleration on that steep re-entry have killed your Kerbals?

frankly, yes. if suffering through 40 Gs has no effect on the crew or ship whatsoever, I'd rather they just take out the G Meter altogether.

I remember a while back there was a challenge to get as many G's without going out farther than the Mun's orbit. I could barely muster about 30 but some guys were hitting around 50, 60, even 70 G's I think. That must have been rough for those Kerbals. Oh and you have to make sure they lived I think, that's were I was always screwed over.

Because the game isn't done.

I like your style sir!

frankly, yes. if suffering through 40 Gs has no effect on the crew or ship whatsoever, I'd rather they just take out the G Meter altogether.

It's good to have it in, yes my Kerbals are unaffected by G's but still it's nice to know if I do this reentry I get so many G's. Which will help when pancaking Kerbals becomes possible

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stapp

This guy survived 46.2g. From what i'd heard, as long as they are not sustained forces, people are able to survive quite high g.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stapp

This guy survived 46.2g. From what i'd heard, as long as they are not sustained forces, people are able to survive quite high g.

The crew won't survive, you should add the spacecraft's durability to the calculation. 40G during re-entry will probably disintegrate the vehicle.

Because the game isn't done.

Bingo. Otherwise "challenges" like this one wouldn't work, because there's no re-entry gameplay yet.

There's a huge difference between instantaneous Gs and sustained Gs. High speed auto crashes during races have produced over 200 instantaneous Gs and the driver survived, but typically over 100 Gs is fatal. Colonel Stapp (as noted above) survived over 40 Gs for several seconds. Longer sustained Gs are survivable up to about 10.

I assume the KSP G-meter reports max instantaneous Gs, but I have no way to tell for sure.

The meter requires it to be sustained over a certain time, or somewhat stable over that time. While doing the maximum mgforce challenge, I got a reading of something like 60g's. However, taking the velocity data from my flight, my actual maximum deceleration was closer to 100 or 120g's.
if the 40 Gs happened during re-entry, it was sustained exposure. I saw the meter flip up to 15 (thats the max) and stay there for at least 4 seconds
